library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(sf)
library(rnaturalearth)

# Theme ------------------------------------------------------------------------
theme_map <- function() {
  theme_void() +
    theme(
      plot.title = ggtext::element_markdown(
        face = "bold",
        hjust = 0,
        size = rel(1.4)
      ),
      plot.subtitle = ggtext::element_markdown(
        hjust = 0,
        size = rel(1.1),
        margin = margin(t = 5, b = 10)
      ),
      plot.caption = ggtext::element_markdown(
        hjust = 0,
        size = rel(0.8),
        color = "grey50",
        margin = margin(t = 5, b = 5)
      )
    )
}

# My hiatus

It’s been quite a while since I posted anything on this blog. Honestly, I had just gotten really busy with my PhD. It got to the point where I was writing so much that the last thing I wanted to do was write something else (i.e., a blog post). However, after a **seven-month hiatus**, I decided it was time to jump back in and do something cool.

And what better way to start than with something from **#TidyTuesday** - probably my favourite excuse to dive into data visualization.

# Tuberculosis data

This week's dataset explores **global tuberculosis (TB) burden estimates** from the *World Health Organization (WHO)*. TB remains one of the world’s most persistent infectious diseases, with mortality rates that vary widely by region and decade. The WHO estimates that 10.6 million people fell ill with TB in 2021, and 1.6 million died from the disease. Monitoring TB burden is essential to guide national responses and global strategies.

For this post, I wanted to focus specifically on **Europe**, visualizing how TB mortality (excluding HIV-related cases) has changed across countries and years.
